Although elevated prenatal exposure to stress hormones is implicated in the development of an asymmetrical phenotype, no published studies have yet examined whether typical variations in foetal cortisol exposure are associated with subsequent variance in fluctuating asymmetry in humans.  The proposed study will therefore examine whether mid-trimester amniotic cortisol levels are associated with subsequent fluctuating asymmetry in finger lengths within three cohorts of children from the UK, Portugal, and Germany.


2. Methods

The current project aims to investigate whether fluctuating asymmetry in finger lengths is correlated with prenatal cortisol exposure as measured via amniocentesis.  To this end, we will analyse three separate cohorts spanning three countries: the UK, Portugal, and Germany.  While some heterogeneity exists between the three cohorts, similar measures were recorded, so meta-analysis of the effect sizes observed in each should yield a robust study of the relationship between amniotic cortisol exposure and fluctuating asymmetry.

2.1 Sample 1: Düsseldorf, Germany

For the German dataset, digit lengths were tracked longitudinally in infants initially from around 5 months of age to 70 months of age.  All finger length measurements (2D, 3D, 4D, and 5D) were measured from photocopies by two independent raters using Autometric (DeBruine, 2006).  Covariates collected for this cohort include maternal age, and sex of the infant.  Further details relating to this cohort can be found in Körner et al. (2019) and Körner, Schaper, Pause, and Heil (2020).

2.2 Sample 2: London, UK

Within the UK dataset, all measurements of digit length (2D and 4D) were taken between 473 and 568 days post-partum.  Digit lengths were taken by two separate researchers, and provided as an average of the two.  Alongside these key variables, a number of covariates were recorded, which include maternal age, gestational age of the infant at amniocentesis, sex of the infant, birth weight, ethnicity of the mother, BMI of the mother, cigarette and alcohol intake during pregnancy, antenatal stressful life events, and the presence of several medical conditions (anxiety disorders, psychotic disorders, eating disorders, and metabolic disorders).  Further details relating to this cohort are provided in Bergman, Glover, Sarkar, Abbott, and O’Connor (2010).

2.3 Sample 3: Lisbon, Portugal

Within the Portuguese dataset, digit lengths (2D and 4D) were measured from photocopies created shortly after birth (range = 2.35-541.32 hours post-partum), with average values being calculated from the measurements of two researchers.  Other covariates recorded include maternal age, gestational age of partum, gestational age of the infant at amniocentesis, ethnicity of mother, infant weight, and sex of the infant.  Further details relating to this cohort can be found in Ventura, Gomes, and Carreira (2012) and Ventura, Gomes, Pita, Neto, and Taylor (2013).

2.4 Fluctuating asymmetry

Composite standardised fluctuating asymmetry of 2D and 4D (and additionally 3D and 5D for the German dataset) will be calculated for each cohort as described by Voracek (2009, p .107).


3. Hypotheses and analysis plan

The normality of distribution for the digit length and amniotic cortisol measures will be tested using the Shapiro-Wilk test for each cohort.  Assuming p is greater than 0.05, parametric hypothesis testing can be applied.  If p is smaller than 0.05, log transformation of the data will be applied, and normality will be retested on the log transformed data.  If the data are still considerably non-normally distributed, bootstrapped (10,000 samples) parametric analyses will be conducted using the original (i.e. non-transformed) variables.

H1: Within the German data set, levels of composite fluctuating asymmetry measured longitudinally will increase over time, with measurements taken at 5M, 9M, 20M, 40M and 70M
	We will apply repeated measures testing to investigate the within-individual comparisons across the months of recording.  As outlined by Palestis and Trivers (2016), a repeated-measures general linear model (GLM) analysis with level of fluctuating asymmetry recorded as the key outcome variable will be conducted for all individuals recorded over at least two different time points.  Assuming the repeated measure (months post-partum of recording) is statistically significant (i.e. p is smaller than 0.05), this will be taken as evidence of within-individual changes in fluctuating asymmetry with age.  Within the GLM, the interaction between amniotic cortisol and age at fluctuating asymmetry measurement (i.e. 5M, 9M, 20M, 40M, and 70M) will also be investigated, as theoretically it seems logical that if fluctuating asymmetry is to increase over time, high cortisol exposure could increase the rate of that change.  These relationships will initially be investigated at the univariate level, and then with maternal age and sex of the infant included as covariates.

H2: Mid-trimester amniotic cortisol exposure will correlate positively with composite fluctuating asymmetry within the German dataset
	If no evidence for H1 is found, average fluctuating asymmetry scores for 2D, 3D, 4D, and 5D across 5M, 9M, 20M, 40M, and 70M will be calculated for each individual.  Not all participants were measured at all time points, so only applicable measurements can be summated.  Average fluctuating asymmetry scores will then be calculated by dividing the fluctuating asymmetry scores for each digit by the number of time-points at which it was measured.  Composite fluctuating asymmetry will then be calculated from these measurements using the formula specified by Voracek (2009).
	If H1 is supported by the prior analysis and fluctuating asymmetry does appear to increase with time, the cross-section of age of measurement with the largest available sample size will be used to calculate composite fluctuating asymmetry using the formula specified by Voracek (2009).
	A Pearson’s correlational analysis will be performed to examine the strength of the relationship between amniotic cortisol exposure and composite fluctuating asymmetry.
	A multiple linear regression model will be fitted with amniotic cortisol exposure as the predictor, composite fluctuating asymmetry as the outcome, and the following as covariates: maternal age, and sex of the infant (male or female).

H3: Mid-trimester amniotic cortisol exposure will correlate positively with composite fluctuating asymmetry within the UK dataset
	A Pearson’s correlational analysis will be performed to examine the strength of the relationship between amniotic cortisol exposure and composite fluctuating asymmetry.
	A multiple linear regression analysis will be fitted with amniotic cortisol exposure as the predictor, composite fluctuating asymmetry as the outcome, and the following as covariates: maternal age, gestational age of the infant at amniocentesis, sex of the infant (male or female), birth weight, ethnicity of the mother (White/Caucasian or not White/Caucasian), BMI of the mother, cigarette and alcohol intake during pregnancy (any intake or none), antenatal stressful life events (any or none), and the presence of several medical conditions (anxiety disorders, psychotic disorders, eating disorders and metabolic disorders [presence of any or presence of none]).

H4: Mid-trimester amniotic cortisol exposure will correlate positively with composite fluctuating asymmetry within the Portuguese dataset
	A Pearson’s correlational analysis will be performed to examine the strength of the relationship between amniotic cortisol exposure and composite fluctuating asymmetry.
	A multiple linear regression analysis will be fitted with amniotic cortisol exposure as the predictor, composite fluctuating asymmetry as the outcome, and the following as covariates: maternal age, gestational age of partum, gestational age of the infant at amniocentesis, ethnicity of mother (White/Caucasian or not White/Caucasian), infant weight, and sex of the infant (male or female).

H5: Meta-analysis of the effect size estimates for each cohort will provide robust evidence of a positive correlation between amniotic cortisol exposure and composite fluctuating asymmetry
	As fluctuating asymmetry is a proximate measure of developmental instability and not the causal variable itself, the correlation between fluctuating asymmetry and amniotic cortisol exposure is expected to systematically underestimate the true strength of correlation between developmental instability and amniotic cortisol exposure.  Thus, it is imperative to use an appropriately powered study to investigate this hypothesised relationship.  We therefore intend to meta-analyse the individual effect sizes observed for each of the three cohorts.
	Assuming there is no major change when covariates are entered into the models for any of Study 1, 2, and 3, unadjusted effect sizes will be used.  If significant covariate effects are observed for any of Study 1, 2 or 3, Cohen’s f2 will be calculated as the effect size from each of the multivariate analyses listed above for each cohort.
	A random-effects meta-analysis will be conducted using the R package metafor (Viechtbauer, 2010) to investigate the overall relationship between amniotic cortisol exposure and composite fluctuating asymmetry across the three cohorts.

attributes.title: Replication of Gardiner and Java (1990)
attributes.description: Registration of Experiment 4. The registration was finalized in December 2019 but apparently not uploaded to the OSF.

summary.value:
In two previous experiments we have failed to recreate Gardiner and Java’s findings from their Experiment 2. In a third experiment, however, we replicate their
sure/unsure findings.

The replication of their Experiment 3 with sure/unsure ratings was particularly
important as our experiments were slightly different in procedure. Specifically, we
used a 10 minute delay instead of 24 hours and we presented more to-be-remembered
items (60 in Experiment 1 and 50 in Experiment 2). The preregistration documents
for these experiments detail the rationale for these changes.

For our previous experiments we were unable to obtain the original words and
non-words used by Gardiner and Java (1990). We were also unable to obtain the
full original instructions presented to participants. During a review process we were
made aware of two published articles that were closely related to Gardiner and Java
(Geraci, McCabe, & Guillory, 2009; Rajaram, Hamilton, & Bolton, 2002). Rajaram
et al. (2002) used the original 30 words and 30 non-words from Gardiner and
Java and added an additional 30 of each so that remember/know and sure/unsure
judgements could be run within subjects (in separate sessions). Geraci et al. (2009)
used the stimuli from Rajaram et al. (2002). Both studies used the remember/know
instructions from Rajaram (1993). Indeed, Geraci et al. (2009) argue that the
findings of Gardiner and Java (Experiment 2) are recreated with these instructions
(although see below) and not with a different set of instructions (from Yonelinas,
2001). The 60 words and 60 non-words were kindly shared with us by Dr. Rajaram
and the instruction text was printed in Rajaram (1993; Geraci et al., 2009; and
Rajaram et al., 2002)

Thus the aim of the present experiment was to try to replicate Gardiner and Java’s
findings from their Experiment 2 using stimuli and instructions that have been used
in papers that claim to find the same underlying pattern of results.
